headline.print_headline: BBC Causes Uproar by Reporting Queen’s Opinion
headline.seo: BBC Reporter Shocks by Reporting Queen’s Opinion
headline.main: BBC Causes Uproar by Reporting Queen’s Opinion

docs.snippet: In what is considered a breach of etiquette, a BBC correspondent said that Queen Elizabeth had once told him she was “pretty upset” about a radical cleric in London....

keywords.value: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
keywords.name: persons

docs.abstract: BBC correspondent Frank Gardner creates uproar by declaring in a radio interview that Queen Elizabeth once told him she was upset about the presence of radical Islamist cleric Abu Hamza in North London; revealing the opinions of the queen is considered a shocking breach of etiquette, especially when it comes to political opinions, which she is not supposed to have.
docs.lead_paragraph: In what is considered a breach of etiquette, a BBC correspondent said that Queen Elizabeth had once told him she was “pretty upset” about a radical cleric in London.

headline.print_headline: Iran Expands on Claim of Sabotage From Abroad of Nuclear and Other Technology
headline.seo: Iran Reveals More About What It Calls Foreign Sabotage Acts
headline.main: Iran Reveals More About What It Calls Foreign Sabotage

docs.snippet: An announcement by the Intelligence Ministry did not specify the intended targets, but said they included nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations....
docs.abstract: Iran says it has amassed new evidence of attempts by saboteurs to attack Iranian nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations, including use of computer virus-infected American, French and German equipment; announcement reflects growing Iranian concern about such security threats as nation deals with increasing international tensions over Iran’s disputed nuclear program.
docs.lead_paragraph: An announcement by the Intelligence Ministry did not specify the intended targets, but said they included nuclear, defense, industrial and telecommunications installations.

headline.print_headline: Blasts Hit Syrian School As War Is Focus at the U.N.
headline.seo: Bombs Hit Damascus School Said to Be Military Center
headline.main: Blasts Hit Syrian School as War Is Focus at the U.N.

docs.snippet: The conflict’s scope widened as Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel....

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Insurgents bomb a Damascus school building and Syrian government shells land in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel, underscoring the Syrian conflict’s growing scope as it dominates much of the discussion on the first formal day of the United Nations General Assembly.

byline.original: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and STEVEN LEE MYERS
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times reported from Damascus, and Steven Lee Myers from New York. Reporting was contributed by Kareem Fahim from Antakya, Turkey; Neil MacFarquhar from the United Nations; Hania Mourtada from Beirut, Lebanon; Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates; and Jodi Rudoren from Jerusalem.

docs.lead_paragraph: The conflict’s scope widened as Syrian government shells landed in the disputed Golan Heights region held by Israel.

headline.print_headline: Germany Is Expected to Act to Increase Limits on High-Speed Trades
headline.seo: Germany Is Expected to Act to Curb High-Speed Trades
headline.main: Germany Acts to Increase Limits on High-Speed Trades

docs.snippet: The rules would require passage by both houses of Parliament, and have been written with an eye toward similar legislation that could eventually apply across the European Union....
docs.abstract: Germany approves draft legislation that foresees imposing additional controls on high-frequency trading, computer-driven force that has been rattling stock markets across the globe; country would become one of the first to attempt to regulate such trades.

byline.original: By MELISSA EDDY and JAMES KANTER
byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy reported from Berlin and James Kanter from Brussels. Jack Ewing contributed reporting from Frankfurt and Nathaniel Popper from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: The rules would require passage by both houses of Parliament, and have been written with an eye toward similar legislation that could eventually apply across the European Union.
